title: 103_s1661
content: The "Worker Protection Warnings Act of 1993" is referenced in the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. The Congress finds that the absence of uniform warnings for personal protective equipment for occupational use increases worker exposure to workplace injuries and illnesses. The absence of Federal standards leaves questions about the adequacy of warnings to be determined by inconsistent State requirements, placing a burden on interstate commerce. The purpose of this Act is to enhance workplace safety by clarifying the proper use of personal protective equipment through uniform warnings. It also aims to preempt any conflicting State standards regarding the adequacy of these warnings. Section 6 (29 U.S.C. 655) is amended to establish uniform warnings for personal protective equipment for occupational use within 12 months of enactment. Personal protective equipment includes gear for eyes, face, head, hearing, extremities, or respiratory tract protection in the workplace. The Act aims to protect workers by requiring uniform warnings for personal protective equipment within 12 months. Personal protective equipment includes gear for eyes, face, head, hearing, extremities, or respiratory tract protection in the workplace. The term 'warning' directs actions or procedures related to the use of personal protective equipment to prevent personal injury or death. Each standard issued under the Act requires warnings for personal protective equipment to be communicated to employees, along with training on proper use and application in the workplace. The standard issued under the Act mandates warnings for personal protective equipment to be communicated to employees, along with training on proper use and consequences of non-compliance. The effective date for these standards is 6 months after publication in the Federal Register, with exemptions for equipment placed in interstate commerce before the effective date unless warnings are communicated to the employer. The standard mandates warnings for personal protective equipment to be communicated to employees, with exemptions for equipment placed in interstate commerce before the effective date unless warnings are communicated to the employer. The Secretary considers factors like manufacturer experience and means of communication for warnings when promulgating standards. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. Section 4 and Section 18 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act are amended to clarify that Congress intends to regulate warnings for personal protective equipment and prevent states from establishing different standards for personal protective equipment once federal standards are in place. The Occupational Safety and Health Act prohibits states from establishing different standards for personal protective equipment once federal standards are in place.
